title: Diary, reminiscences, and correspondence of Henry Crabb Robinson ...
author: Robinson, Henry Crabb

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: a medical student at Edinburgh and Ley den, and a vagabond a fluting and disputing vagabond over half Europe ! And over here, he'd tried play-acting, physicking  poor people I remember your mentioning that on the Bankside, that night you were so mellow two years ago besides proof-correcting for Sam Richardson, school-mastering, and, worst of all, hack-writing for Griffiths the bookseller.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " The place is lovely " here his eye rested on the scene before us "so's the country round ; but for getting near to Shakespeare give me the Bankside ! "

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: Mr. Fairfield admitted that when on the Bankside I had assured him that there was no more beautiful prospect in England, I spoke nothing but the truth.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " I noticed in the old maps of the Bankside  that there were stairs at every few paces, and no doubt it was just the same on the other side.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: The tall steeple was burnt down a little before Shakespeare's time, but the body of the cathedral would still be the most prominent object from Bankside ; it would show high above all the surrounding buildings."

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: I was disposed to agree, but I thought that my friend was forgetting how much more than the lanes and alleys still remained to recall to us the Bankside of 300 years ago.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: Between Horseshoe Alley and the Anchor Tavern, which occupies  the angle that is formed by the juncture of Bankside  and Bankend, there was an unbroken line of brick and mortar.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " There is at the Museum a map of the Bankside as it existed in James I's time," said Mr. Fairfield, as we stood about half-way down, " and it shows that there was just the same odd angle here then as we see now before us.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: The Bankside by night was a far less prosaic place than it had seemed by daylight.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " I have often thought," he remarked meditatively as we bowled along eastward, " what a privilege it is to be able to visit interesting places like the Bankside whenever you like, and particularly at night-time.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: In imagination I traced the path from the King's Arms back to the Bankside.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " Oh, yes, every Londoner knew it, and the Bankside people had it close at hand.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: At the Museum I found on a survey of the Bankside, that was made on vellum in Queen Elizabeth's time, a millpond  marked at the top of Gravel Lane, and in Rocque's great plan of 1746 there the pond was again ; and I assure you, sir " here he became so impressive, that he leaned forward with his elbows on the table and emphasised his disclosure with a wagging forefinger " that cocoa place you remember what a wide curve the front has occupies the exact site of that pond, and follows the very outline of it."

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: Oddly enough," he continued, leaning forward and becoming confidential, " I found on dipping into Pennant's description of the Bankside, that there was a house there not at all a pretty kind of house which bore the sign of the Cardinal' s Hat.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " Well, sir, there was an out-at-elbows look about the place that rather disappointed me at first, and, somehow,  I found it difficult to associate it with the Bankside  of Queen Elizabeth's time ; but when I came to think things over, the recollection of that big river, so close at hand and so open, and those passages with their quaint names, took hold of me.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " I am very much indebted to you for showing me the Bankside," he said after an interval of silence.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: Two or three weeks after our visit to the Bankside, I dined with Mr. Fairfield in Soho, at a restaurant that was once the dwelling of Edmund Burke.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: We had now reached the end of Bankside, and were within a few yards of Messrs. Epps' cocoa-works, round which Holland Street curls.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: We had met very few people earlier in our ramble, except  in the Borough High Street, and on the Bankside we had met nobody.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: "It looks," I said after a prolonged scrutiny, "like an H over a B and an S probably the B. S. means Bankside," I hazarded as a guess " and a little lower down there is on one side of the pipe 17 and on the other 12."

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " I'll be bound there isn't one Londoner in ten thousand  who has ever been on the Bankside, or seen this view," he remarked at length.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: He seemed little disposed to find anything to commend  on the Bankside, but there was no denying the majesty of the prospect that lay before us.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: Some fifty yards farther on, the roadway of the Bankside  widens out, and there are no objects on the waterside  to interfere with the view.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: "Did you see it printed on that jug on the counter ' The White Bear, Bankside ' ? Not an unlikely address, sir, for a letter of Shakespeare's time."

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " I am quite content," he said, following out the quotation  in his own mind ; but never a word in praise of the Bankside did he utter.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: It must have destroyed many landmarks on the Bankside.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " The Bankside ends there," I explained, pointing to that corner.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: I did not dare to speak more positively ; for though I had known the Bankside for many years, and had read a good deal about it in a desultory way, I did not feel strong enough to be put to the question, and called upon to give chapter and verse for my knowledge.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " The Bankside no, I haven't seen it," he answered meditatively ; and then with a quickened interest he went on, " I've read of it, of course Shakespeare and the old playhouses.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " And the Bankside do you know that?

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Under the auspices of his friend and countryman, Goldsmith commenced practice as a physicianabout the Bankside, and afterwards near the Temple ; and although unsuccessful in procuring fees,had soon plenty of patients.
